review_title: One of the best VR games.
one_reviews_text:
A unique concept, engrossing atmosphere, and memorable characters...this game has it all. The voice-acting, models and animation quality are top-notch, and the game has a very decent length to it as well.

The setting is reminiscent of a retro comic book horror-mystery, filled with memorable moments and dark humor. It has a meaningful ending which doesn't feel rushed like most games.

The only thing that could be a downside is that sometimes it wasn't quite clear what you could (or should) do to progress further.

All in all, this is one of the hidden gems of VR. An amazing experience, and will remain a must-play for years to come 👍

I play this every Halloween since it launched. It's just the right kind and amount of horror for me. A game made for Oculus Touch and it shows right from the opening scene, making you very aware that your hands play an important role in the upcoming adventure. So much, in fact, that the game's entire concept is wrapped around using your hands to manipulate VR in interesting, albeit natural ways. The game controls the direction and scene, allowing you to choose pre-selected spots to travel to. This may be off putting for some, but is absolutely necessary in the way the game brilliantly directs the story, action, puzzles and pace. It achieves a perfect blend of VR comfort and difficultly that allows for just about anyone to jump in. No backtracking! Even the boss fights won't back track: If you die while on, say, the 3rd sequence level of a boss, you'll restart on the 3rd sequence (nice! it respects your time and won't bore you with having to do the same actions over and over again). All the characters in the game are hyper-quality in their textures, animations, voice overs and interactions.  The little details that are there, like the way their eyes follow you, make it really feel like you're in the room with another person. Amazing story, satisfying and actually pretty emotional ending if you pay attention to the ending (stay after the credits!). You'll know why the main character is such a pessimistic hardass. A masterpiece. It really does feel like you're inside a Twilight Zone episode. Absolutely brilliant. Wish we got more like this one for VR.

review_title: Excellent game with a few flaws
one_reviews_text:
Overall, great game! Very immersive graphics-- and you'll know the possible good reason for the monochrome style when you reach the very end after the credits scene. Wonderful set pieces, especially the ending. You feel you are within a movie, definitely.

Now, a few small flaws. First is some wonky control bugs here and there like when you throw stuff or sometimes when you wear stuff like gloves and push elevator buttons LOL. You'll know what I mean when you get there. Also the combat piece seem to be overdone, with very repetitive patterns as well as literally repetitive combat.

Let us end on a great note, though. Again, excellent game. The story is solid. The puzzles are self-guiding, and though some may be "WTF?!", but in the end, it's fun to think out of the box as an escape from our world of "logic". So had a lot of fun playing this one. No regrets :)

I've seen this game played on Youtube, and decided to give it a go. My first AAA game on my headset was Half Life: Alyx. While this isn't as innovative (or massive), the gameplay and graphics offered here are rock solid. I played it on my Quest 2, with Medium settings (high had my computer screaming too loudly, lol). The character details/textures are amazing! I love the black and white filter. It works here. The characters all feel like real people, and it truly feels like you're playing in an old horror film. The Fly scene got me, especially since I HATE bugs lol! I found myself studying the character designs more than actually listening to them, lol! Didn't mind the look-and-click teleporation to traverse areas. Excellent choice for people who aren't used to VR and may experience motion sickness. The puzzles are simple, and the boss fights are slightly repetative once you recognize their patterns, but highly entertaining. The voice acting is top notch, and the character animations are convincing. Not a lot of items to interact with beyond bottles you can break and a few light switches (not couting the items you need to progress the story), but the game doesn't need that "sandbox" feel. The story is engaing, and the sound design and use of perspective/scale are amazing. First time in VR? This is a great introduction! Get it!

As a dedicated VR enthusiast of seven or so years, I feel compelled to defend Wilson's Heart against more recent negative reviews. Yes, Half Life Alyx is absolute GOLD! I kinda wept a bit in my headset when first seeing City 17 from the opening balcony. Asgard's Wrath is some of the purest, most amazing gaming I have ever done in my four decades of video games. But, man, how quickly we turn on true innovation! Wilson's Heart is nearly four years old. Folks are now trashing it for its "antiquated" mechanics and node interface, when at the time - JUST four years ago - it was stellar! Wilson's Heart is an absolutely gorgeous, tension filled, well written, highly produced masterpiece! For those who have not played it - go into it with an open mind. Expect a game where standing STILL (not turning around all the time) and turning your head and using nodes is expected. Again, it's four years old. It is still beautiful, deep, fun, unexpected, with great voice acting and set pieces. W's H also has one of the most engaging story lines of any game ever made for VR. If you want a run and gun FPS then don't buy it. But if you want a fun and rare and unique (in a good way) gaming experience don't hesitate on it. It uses teleportation nodes and it DOES have 360 degree movement - though you will often have to reorient your body in your play space if you turn too much. That doesn't mean the game isn't wonderful. It absolutely is.

There's a lot to like: graphics look amazing on Rift S. Very sharp visuals, great characters, good dialogues and interesting story. Oh, and it's all in black and white! I was worried lack of colours will make visuals boring after a while, but it didn't. It looks awesome and it feels like you'd be in an old monster movie.

Gameplay is great as well. Puzzles are not hard, but what sells the experience are hands interactions. In a way those are puzzles on their own. You can see devs really tried to bank on back-then-novelty of having hands in VR and the game keeps surprising you with the ways you can interact with your hands. The most important thing though: it still works and feels fresh and original even 3 years latter.

The only part of the game that kind of disappoints are boss fights. Bosses look great and the fights are actually puzzles: you need to figure out the successful pattern. The problem is, once you figure this out, it's not challenging anymore, but you still need to repeat it over and over again. It's not a big problem and it's still fun, but it would be better if you'd only have to figure out a pattern and be done with he boss and not repeat it 3 or 4 times.

Despite this small criticism, I was absolutely enjoying the game and can't recommend it enough!

I loved this game and it was great to play. The atmosphere is terrific, the script well written, even has some well setup scarry bits. This would be my top game and would score 5* if it were not for the control and movements implementation ,this I found very frustrating.  

It is not a free form game where movement is unlimited and I really wish it was. There were many item I wish I could have investigated but could not. However the game may have been too diffcult to play in an open free movement style game.

I'll just go through my positives and negatives of the game. At the end of the day though, I'd say the game is overpriced for what it offers.

POSITIVES
* It has an OK story. Much better than most games of this time. This is honestly the best part of the whole game. Any scene you are in when interacting with characters is interesting because of the dialogue. If you are looking for a VR game solely for a good story, it isn't a bad choice.
* Good visuals. I don't think I ever once thought the visuals were lacklustered through my playthrough

NEGATIVES
* It offers a 10 hour experience and I beat it in 5 (and I took my sweet time with it)
* Teleportation to get to where you need to go BUT severely limited (as in you can only teleport to highlighted spots)... This is likely because-
* The puzzles can sometimes be very arbitrary and you are basically teleporting to find the shiny highlighted object on the map in order to progress.
* The boss fights. Oh God the boss fights. So basically boss fights are a puzzle and you have to figure out how to stop a boss from attacking you, sometimes with very unintuitive ways. This can lead to some frustration as you have to watch boss entrance animations over and over again until you figure out what to do. Once you figure out what to do, the rule of three hits applies to the bosses. So you have to solve the puzzle you know how to easily solve now 3 times and this can take forever. You basically just sit down in a chair and move your hands around to solve the puzzle for 5 minutes over and over again until it's finally dead. Not very fun.
*This is not a horror game unless your scare tolerance is that of thinking apples are inherently terrifying. Of course the few jumpscares will getcha, I mean of course they will as you are in VR and they are a cheap form of scare tactics. If you came here looking for a genuinely horrifying mood (think Dead Space, Aliens, or The Thing) then you will be very dissapointed. It Has mood of self aware comedy.

review_title: So close to being truly epic
one_reviews_text: I will say that this game is well produced and is quite the VR story telling horror experience. The visuals and audio are on point, and the touch controls work wonderfully with the design. Overall the game is wonderful, but there is one key  reason I can't give it a higher score: The Locomotion. In this game you teleport between pre-determined locations which is not unheard of in VR titles, however, they force a different orientation each time you are teleported. For example, if you are facing forward and teleport to a doorway ahead in a hallway, once you teleport you are no longer facing forward- you are facing sideways (if the silhoutte was facing sideways.) This is incredibly jarring and really pulls you out of the immersion you may have been feeling before. Had they decided to let you teleport and maintain the direction you were already facing this would have been much smoother, but them forcing you to rotate every time you teleport is a bit frustrating. (I played with a 3 sensor 360 tracking setup) Also, if you try to look at the scenery around you and take  a step away from the center of your play space, the game pauses until you reset your position. This is a shame as the level design was brilliant and you want to take it all in naturally- but are forced to stand in place essentially. This game is great if you can get past the locomotion, but for me it really took a lot away from the experience.

10/10
Incredible. One of the best gaming experiences I have had. A must have for VR gamers.

At some parts of the game I was really confused what to do, what to interact with etc they should make this a little bit more obvious (things like breaking the glass, burning the book etc).

If you are looking for a horror game, this might not be your best bet. At moments there are small jump scares but it's nothing out of the ordinary. If you are looking for a scary game like Dreadhalls then this game might not offer your needs.

review_title: Amazing atmosphere and acting, has flaws
one_reviews_text:
This is quite a well produced piece of entertainment. The voice acting is very well done (except for Peter Weller's death scream - they must have got that one on his way out the door). The characters are enthralling and the scenery and music is wonderful. 

The setting really captures the creepiness and there are a few jump scares, but overall there is a suspense and tension that keeps you anxious and uncomfortable.

There are a couple of aspects to the 'game' portion that make it a little less enjoyable and pull you out of the story. A lot of the 'boss fights' rely on you figuring something out relatively quickly without much prompting, and it can be a little bit of trial and error. Unfortunately the way they executed these fights is you die, fade to black, try again. Over and over until you hit upon what the designers want you to do. There was one fight where I must have died 20 times. They trained me to use a device (type of weapon) in one fashion, then expected me to use it in a completely different fashion in the middle of the fight. It becomes a little nauseating looping over and over and hearing the protaganist's half hearted death scream.

There are also some clunky mechanics in the game involving manipulating objects like keys and doors. I think we have come a long way with regards to object manipulation since this title was released (reviewing it in October 2018). The puzzles are not particularly hard, usually there is not much guessing as your inventory serves up the object you need at the appropriate time. This is best described as an interactive movie with puzzles/fights.

All in all, I would say I enjoyed the story and characters more than enough to compensate for the flaws I experienced.  Some people might be sharper and not have to die as many times as I did before they get it right. 

The voice acting really shines and brings the story to life. Overall it is a wonderful experience. Even the end credits are entertaining. Play if you have the chance.

From the beginning, this game latches onto you and pulls you in.  From everything to feeling like you are a major charactor in all of those old black and white monster movies (but more mature versions), to catching little things like references to RoboCop and other pop culture--this is by far my favorite VR experience.  

They constantly add new game mechanics and every scene or "level" adds something new to experiment with and to change gameplay or add to it.

Absolutely a blast to play and to experience!

I had a really great time playing through the game. I love the environment and sound/music. I've never really gotten jump scared in a game before this, I think it worked because I was really "into" the game. The game movement of exploring rooms with jump cuts reminded me of the original resident evil games when you walk through doors. Standing in darkness waiting and listening to creepy sounds adds to the intensity. I also surprisingly enjoyed stopping and reading through the comics/books/newspapers in the game I just wish the lighting in those areas was better because I was often hunched over uncomfortably trying to get just the right angle.  I only got stuck on a few areas, so I never felt too frustrated to wuity. I do wish the boss matches were a bit more dynamic but that was just a minor issue. I hope I can find some more great titles like this!

This game actually makes it feel like your fighting monsters and walking through a haunted hospital. The mechanics are great and most of the actions you preform feel natural to the task. The story is great as well and one of the best on VR.

AMAZING FEATS OF INGENUITY!
This with haptic suits et al and vr's got one hell of a future.

Perhaps the most emotional moving experience I've done on the Rift. The story is surreal and weird, the main thought running through my head while playing it was: this is art. And really impressive art at that. More than a game.

review_title: I want more games like this!
one_reviews_text: I just completed the game.  I really enjoy everyting like story line, B/W color environment, fears here and there, combats etc. The length of the game is just perfect, not too short nor too long. The puzzle to get from one location to another was good level of complexity, not too hard nor to easy. Thank you for this great game! Please do another one in color thi stime :)

review_title: Brilliant Game! There needs to be more!
one_reviews_text: I loved every second of this game and I am glad I bought it, even at full price. This game is very beautiful and graphically impressive. I am more into action type games but this story gripped me from start to finish. The puzzles in this game were very well made. They were a bit challenging but not to the point of pulling hairs, and I am terrible at puzzle games. The game also has some interesting fighting scenes that are each very different from the last so the game always feels fresh. The only thing that I dont like about the game is, even though the story was fairly long, it took me about 3 days, 2-3 hours each day, to beat it. I was sad that it ended and I would love more stories like this and maybe even a sequel! But the shortness of the story still didnt deter my five star rating and 30 dollars spent. Well worth it

review_title: Wow - an actual AAA title in VR!
one_reviews_text: Splendid graphics and storyline.  Surprisingly good! I thought this would just be another horror title that over-promises and under-delivers.  I was wrong, this game is really good! Not too hard, but that's a good thing. This is about enjoying the plot, not getting frustrated by puzzles.

review_title: One of the best experiences in VR
one_reviews_text: The controls are constrained to fixed teleporting locations which bothered me at first, but it has one of the best stories and lots of detail compared to anything else I've played.  One of my favorite VR titles even if it is a bit older than most.
Very unique realistic interactions with the environment, great story, fun and satisying combat, 10/10 this is a VR must and given the quality assets, totally worth the money

review_title: From the makers of Loney Echo,
one_reviews_text: This is a simplier version of Loney Echo, basically the same concept of playing the main character of a movie, with some simple puzzles which unlocks check points,  before you can advance to the next chapter and some fun fighting sceens. Where Loney Echo's big leap forward from this earlier release is the free motion and complete interaction with the environment, this game limits the interactive environment my teleporting to a set number of fixed positions, making this a more linear experience. After playing Loney Echo (5 stars), I went back to try other story type games (Obduction, Invisible Hour), but I like the movie type feel of Occulus Studios, compared to the pure puzzle like feel of the other developers. This game had me intertained from beginning to end.

This is a really great game, especially if you're into 40's horror monster movie genre, which I absolutely am! The story isn't the "best", but's still engaging enough. The characters are pretty good, developed enough to like them.

The gameplay, at first, wasn't entirely what I was expecting. I'm used to VR games having some sort of free movement, ala Lone Echo and From Other Suns. In this game, you can only teleport to select spots, so there's really no "free roaming". But, once I managed to get through that little quirk, I was really able to engage in this game, and it's rather interesting what you can find and interact with. And at some point early on, you get a neat device that has multiple functions (I won't spoil much, but it is pretty fun to use). 

There are a couple reasons this isn't getting a 5 star, depsite the very positive view I have of this game. One of the main reasons, is the game sometimes doesn't have much context. Meaning, there were points where I wasn't sure what to do or where to go, because the game never made it clear. For example, there's one part early on, where you're meant to close these steamer doors and lock them. I was able to close them, and I tried turning the bar to lock it, but nothing really happened. I tried wandering around, and couldn't figure anything out. Turns out, you need to use *both* hands to lock the door, and the game in no way clues you into that, you're just meant to figure it out on your own somehow. It's not often, but stuff like this does appear throughout the game.

The other reason, is because I feel there was a bit of lost potential with the fun device I mentioned earlier. Although it is a really neat thing to use and is pretty fun using it, you're only able to use it in very pre-determined events, like when enemies appear, or when a certain event occurs. Setting up the game in a way where you can use the device whenever you want would've definitely benefited a lot, but sadly it was a missed opportunity.

This one's been on my wishlist for a while. Finally went on sale so I decided to pick it up. I wish I hadn't waited - definitely worth the full $30. Great experience with a cool creepy atmosphere. A few spoops here and there but certainly nothing over the top. The puzzles are fun and challenging enough to give you satisfaction when you solve them without stopping your progress in frustration. Fun story with good voice acting for the colorful cast of characters. 

The game controls great, although if you're like me and have a roomscale setup, you have to get used to the fact that you can't walk around.

It took me about five hours to complete this one and several months just to play it.  The exploring and puzzle solving is fun, there are only a couple of jump scares, and the graphics look great. The worst part about this game is the fighting. You will fight these monsters throughout the hospital which consists of doing the same thing over and over. God forbid you mess up. If you do fail, it restarts to far back and you just do the same thing over and over again. I would not recommend this game

review_title: To live a great story > playing a game
one_reviews_text: Twisted Pixel has made an incredible game that does more than just entertain. It is an excellent story that you feel as if you have lived instead of played. For any VR fan this is a must have game and for any horror fan it will be even greater than watching your favorite old school horror movie again.

This is a very well polished game. My headset got here before my new gpu did, and because im impatient, I decided to try it out on my GTX 660. it actually runs surprisingly well. It would look even better on an actual gpu meant for VR, but it has liitle to no latency and I experience no VR sickness whatsoever. the story is intriguing, with amazing detail to match! Perfect addition to any VR library!

At first I thought it was gonna be another one of those games that cost too much for what they offer. I was wrong. I am not good at describing experiences but what I can say is that if you dont wanna take my word for it take the 500 other ones. Also the trailer pretty much shows you exactly what you are gonna get if you buy this game so thats a plus as well I quess. I play many horror games and I can safely say this is one of the best... games out there in general not just the horror ones lul.

Easy movement, some real scares and some fun ones. I did need a walkthrough a couple times, but I'm not really a gamer so that might just have been me. 

As you get further into the story, the theme starts to really make sense and you'll find that Wilson is a fun guy to be in a insane nightmare hospital with. Objects are easily interactive and the characters and voice acting are great. 

Fantastic game I absolutely recommend. I played for a six hour session at one point because I  got so into it and as far as I was concerned i WAS a middle aged sacarstic man with a paranormal crazy ball where his heart should be.

One tip;  The doors are push doors PUSH THEM (watching my friend try to pull them all was infuruating)

This game is unique in its presentation. It presents itself like the classic horror films of the 40's and doesn't disappoint. It's an enjoyable game that has a decent story and a wonderful atmosphere. Wilson's Heart limits your freedom by giving you choices on where to move and what actions are allowed. However, this never made the experience feel any less enjoyable. The fight scenes in this game are a bit too easy and the complexity of the puzzles are mediocre. Although this game lacks complexity and the freedom to move about in a locomotive fashion, it's unique enough in the library of VR games to warrant its place as a must-have game. It's a beautiful game with some jump scare moments and an enjoyable, easy to predict story. I truly had a lot of fun with this title and I believe it's worth buying.

review_title: So many great and polished ideas!
one_reviews_text: As I began the game, I thought "yet another game that tries to scare you". But as I advanced through the story, I realized that it's a full-fledged game as you rarely see in VR, with an actual storyline, characters, good music... There are lots of surprises, some of them which I'll remember for a long time. All in all, a must buy. There are some small drawbacks; no free movement (it wouldn't work anyway though, but feels limiting), and the "fights", though fun, feel gimmicky. This being said, you'll only see these mechanics once each time, so really I can't complain. The black and white rendering actually makes it more realistic to me, and interactions are really great (the bath...)

I bought this a few months ago but for some reason I moved on to other games.  I came back and decided to see how the story progressed.  Wow, I'm so glad I fired this back up.  The attention to details is incredible.  All the little transitions and object interactions are perfectly done.  Easily the most polished VR experience I've had (at least on a par with Lone Echo).  Really, really enjoying it.  Runs exceptionally well, great image quality.  Very atmospheric.  Highly recommended.

Okay, so I got this on sale for $9.99, and I feel like I robbed Twisted Pixel. This game is really good, and has a very unique movement system. I definitely didn't expect any of the plot twists, and it was told superbly (not to mention how long it is, my speed run was 5 hours in one sitting). I really felt like I was talking to the characters too, it was so believable. Plus, you aren't a faceless, mute protagonist this time, yay! I had so much fun playing as Wilson, and I thought each character was great, especially Kurt. Fun fact, though. If something like a door or lever isn't working, try using both hands. review_title: A harkening back to Adventure games
one_reviews_text:
This is closer to a first person VR version of the old PC adventure games that died out in the mid-90s than anything else.  Thus, its more an interactive story with puzzles, where you feel very immersed in the weird environment.  An entertaining story that is hard to put down. 

 The only downside is I think $29 is probably too much for it, despite the great artistic effort that clearly went into it as it probably is only 5 hours long total.

The game is very good at using VR to its advantage. It was emmersive. However, I would love if they made the puzzles a bit more tricky, as the game basically tells you what to do. In addition, it is a little short. However, it makes up for these misstakes by an immersive experience and truly scary jumpscares. I would definetly recommend this game, esepcially if it is on sale.

A great atmospheric game,the devs did a great job to implement a great story with good puzzles.   The only thing I would say is it holds your hand a little too much.  It would be nice to have a little more freedom of movement, but I understand why its point to point motion.  I highly recommend playing it.

it took me about 3 - 4 hours to complete it was worth it to me.

review_title: Not perfect, but enjoyable horror romp
one_reviews_text: This game is definitely one of the prettiest and most atmospheric VR games I've played so far. It's basically an interactive horror movie where you solve various puzzles to progress through the rooms of a sinister hospital, with all kinds of ghostly goings on. The story captivates and certainlly compells you to continue further. The acting is first rate, with Peter Welller being the real star as the aponymous hero of the story, I laughed out loud several times through the game, and jumped out of my skin on occasion too. It's not really scary, but there enough uncomfortable moments to make you always a little on edge. The game holds your hand to a certain extent with the puzzles, always pulling the correct objects out of your inventory and highlighting anything that needs interacting with. This will frustrate some, who yearn for more freedom, but even when you are given these large clues, you still have to figure out exactly how to perform the appropriate actions, as there is an awful lot of inventive ways to use the Oculus Touch controls in this. My only gripe with the game is that it forces to you remain in a tiny playspace, blacking out the screen and freezing the action, if you so much as lean forward too far. I don't know why they decided to implement this, I've never experienced such a system with any other VR game before. It's also worth noting the game uses teleportation as a mechanic too. Personally I love teleportation. I'm a little susceptable to motion sickness and I also find pushing a joystic to move clunky and unnatural in virtual reality. I just see teleporting as a transition to a different cut scene like you'd have in a movie. This experience is closer to a movie than a traditional game anyway so it works well in my view. I know some hate the old teleport mechanic however, seeing it as big a breach of their freedoms and liberty as Republicans do any challenge to their second ammendment rights to own a machine gun so I'll just say caveat emptor.
the game is okay, there are some really good moments, but the fights are childish and slow. puzzles are simple, story is weak. the length of the game is fair. probably good for 5-10$

I have had this game for a while and finally had time to play it.  I loved the black and white style and story.  I think that VR needs more wonderful games like this that really tell a compelling story and places you in it.  Small details like the TPS report on the wall, and the fact that the characters eyes follow you when you move is awesome.  Looking forward to a sequal.  (Please make another!)

Hands down the best VR experience I have had. Totally immersive and the attention to detail is just insane.  This game takes full advantage of VR experience and the puzzles and interaction between objects and characters will grab your atention and keep it there. VR can take the mundane and make it magical and Wilsons Heart takes this to another level. My only issue (and it's minor) is that this is a point and click to move type of  game but the game play, attention to detail and storyline are woven together so well that it's easy to forgive and suspend any disbelief. I have been playing this intermittently for about  two weeks. I can see how someone with  more time on their hands could easily get sucked in and play streight through but I will say game play is surprisingly long compared to other oculus games. The  eye candy noir alone is enough to make this my favorite occulus game. If you like suspense and horror with a 50's slant, do your self a favor and just buy this game. You can thank me later.

one_reviews_text:

I've got the Rift for one year now and tested several tech demos and games. For an adventure fan like me this is absolutely amazing. Triple A content. The game mechanics works great and the atmosphere is dense. Superb graphics and the play time is long enough for a game like this. I love it.

I don't want to play while standing.
because I work standing up. 

please help me.

I got Wilson's Heart after a friend recommended it. And I will probably listen to his advice the next time as well. This is a really fun game with a satsifying amount of content. It's definately the best looking game I have played so far on the Rift - and it ran REALLY well on my GTX 970 and i7 2700k (upgraded to different specs mid playthrough but couldn't see a lot of difference in this game).

When you meet other people in this game, I was mind blown. It's something else to meet a NPC that is in your size, staring you into your eyes.

The only thing that drags the score down a notch is that I think that the quality of the scenarios and the "scripted solutions" decrease a bit when the game progresses. The further I got into the game, the more I was frustrated when I couldn't solve a problem the way I felt was a lot more logical than the main character. 

I would definately recommend a purchase. You get a lot of content (about 8 hours), an actual story and an enjoyable experience.

review_title: Good to play with the GF
one_reviews_text: Gf likes a good old thriller novel or Movie, shes not into gaming.  But titles like this in vr are a lot different. Personally id rather play GTA in 2d flat screen, but we have rifts for a different flavour.  We have been entertained taking it in turns.  Reminds me of Day of the tentical  a little bit (point and click game from the 90s).  But have to say if she went out, this would be turned off. There is lots of good stuff in the store, but i have a full time job, so only got time for SUPER AMAZING with my little time.  This is sonly "good" and thus somehwat impressive.

I got this on sale after looking at some of the reviews, well if I knew this was going to be this good I;d have got it at full price!
Started off and was instantly creeped out, got the the bathroom mirror and though hmm something is going to scare the holy bejeezus out of me but it doesn't need those jump scares to make you feel a little uneasy.
The atmosphere around you is enough to make you feel you're alone but not really alone, so entertaining, it felt I was playing through a feature length film, great story a decent length and gameplay which isn't too taxing but well thought out.
But that teddy bear...you'll see.

The story takes all the classic horror movies and puts them in this game. I love the voice acting the gameplay and the creepy feeling. With all vr you have to allow yourself to be immersed. This game had me sweating at times, but the story plays like a who done it. Please make a sequel...or something close. Big fan of this game, I wish I could give it more stars.

I have played this all the way through and have to say it is the best storyline and atmosphere in a VR game I have experienced to date.  Set in 1940's hospital it is absolutely dripping with atmosphere and the environment feels so authentic and detailed.  The black and white graphics actually suit the game perfectly and works better than colour would have done.

It's scary but more down to the atmosphere rather than cheap jump out at you scares (though there are one or two of those).

Despite the 5 stars there are issues with the game.  You are largely led through the puzzles rather than having to work things out for yourself - for example the item you need to use pops up in front of you which essentially gives the puzzles away and items you need to interactive with glow. When I did get stuck it was largely down to not seeing something rather than not be able to work something out or not visiting one location before my current one.    

Your movement is restricted to jumping around set points in the scenes which adds to the feeling of being led through the game.   

I had to give the game 5 stars though because it so brilliantly done and well put together with great graphics and voice acting.  Highly recommend it especially if you are a horror fan.

This is the second VR game I've played that felt like a complete product. From the very beginning, Wilson's Heart creates a dark and eerie atmosphere, complemented by the black and white graphics. Little details such as comics and radio boradcasts drive home the 40's/50's horror movie vibe. This game had the potential to scare me to death, but it's actually pretty light on jump scares. Mainly, it really drives home how terrifying a game like Resident Evil or Dead Space would be in VR. I only had a few issues. 1) Boss fights can be repetitive. 2) You need a ceiling high enough for full throwing motion. 3) Interactions with other objects are often pretty choppy, and it's often not clear where the game wants you to put your hands.

I've played nearly every "popular" oculus game that has come out for the past year. I have been eyeing this one for several months and finally had to pull the trigger when it went on sale for the winter sale. 

I have to say I was a bit skeptical from some of the lower reviews but I LOVED this game/experience. Extremely high quality in every aspect, great story, immersive, fun, silly, overall just a great time and for SURE worth full price. 

If you're on the fence, and enjoy immersive / puzzly / slightly scary / teleport-rails type games then you are going to have an amazing time in this one.

This could have easily been a 5 star game but there is just a few annoyances holding it back. On the positive side, the graphics and setting in which the story takes place is fantastic. The characters and the story are quite interesting in my opinion and I found myself laughing outloud at some of the well timed dark humor. Unfortunately, there are some negative elements that detract from the game. First, interaction is extremely limited in this game and sometimes a bit frustrating. if you lean too far one way or the other you go "out of focus" so you have to make sure you stay planted in a tiny space for each scenario to maintain immersion. Furthermore, most of the objects in the environment can't be interacted with which is quite disappointing and again breaks the immersion. Combat can be frustrating at times (ala creature from the black lagoon) and occasionally a bit lack luster. Overall, a good purchase at the right price.

Wilson's Heart is easily the best Story-Driven Game I have yet played on VR. It is also amongst the finest SDGs I have played in recent years, period. The characters are classic without being riddled by deja vu, and likewise the enemies are familiar, but still feel exciting while they come at you (bugbosssofun). The environment of the game was very appealing to me, reminiscant of Silent Hill and Layers of Fear, but with a more varied content supporting the age-old context. I do have one problem with the game... Whilst most of the gameplay was clean, fun and a great way to show off the different playstyles of VR, there were a couple which were kind of annoying and seemed not to offer enough fulfillment upon completion to outway their tediousness. In particular there is a point where you must throw an object from your palm, around an enemy, to strike a target behind them. This was rather frustrating, not all that clever and if I had had even a tiny bit less space to lean and side-step I do not know if I could have completed the battle without a great many tries. Also, I would personally have liked the fights to be much harder in terms of enemy speed. However, other than these points, I lo-o-oved every moment of this magnificent title.

Wow! This is such an amazing game! Imagine being in a 1950's horror movie and you will get an idea of Wilson's heart. The controls are easy to figure out, inventory system is simplified as to not get in the way of the story. And that's the best part, there is a great story, not just a shooting game. The graphics are great IMO, and the voice acting is top notch.

The only thing I didn't like is the throw mechanic, just seems to not work correctly. You will get about 7 hours of play, and replay is not very high as once you figure out the puzzles you can't exactly forget them. But definate a must have.

The setting is perfect for this type of game. Actually, it's more like an interactive movie. It does take some time to get used to moving around and spotting what it is that they want you to pick-up/use. But, be patient and work it through. I love black & white horror movies and this put me right in one. The puzzles aren't too hard, but again some can be difficult because I missed something and had to go back and look around more. The voiceovers are very well done and the story isn't too fast paced. You can do things at your own pace and not be forced into an arcade game. The controls are a little janky, but not too bad. Overall, a very good atmospheric thriller. There is more to VR than wave shooters.

MANOCHANG - This is not, was not and will not advertise itself as a fighting game. IT IS an atmospheric puzzle game set in a 1940's Horror Hospital. Yes, there is light physical activity at times. It was released in 2017, so your trying to apply 2020 VR logic to it, is mind-numbingly wrong.  

I think you are  a person that has lofty expectations and if not met, it's trash. I suggest that you lower all expectations to middle of the road and adjust them up or down according to your experience at that time, not before. You will find life to be much more livable. Don't be angry all the time. The world is not here for you, you are here for the world. Be kind.

PS - I know that I called him/her out and then said, "be kind".

review_title: Great puzzle game marred by lazy fights
one_reviews_text:
Wilson's Heart is an amazing point and click puzzle game within a vr world.  The story is creative, although the ending feels rushed.
However, my primary problem with the game is how uninspired and repetitive a lot of the fights end up being. The fight scenes do drag a little.  You pretty much have to beat every opponent 3 times, doing the same thing all three times.  Probably an attempt to make the game a little longer since in my opinion it is a little short natively, although not in the extreme.  Also, the strong language seemed a bit out of place much of the time.  I think it was thrown in there to make it feel a bit more edgy in the 40's environment, but didn't usually feel appropriately timed.

Usually I don't like this genre, but with Wilson's Heart it was a great VR experience for me. The programmers did a phantastic job by creating goosebumps not by simple splatter shocker, but more by smart playing with the fear. The b/w picture brings a lot into the immersion. And there are many small things you relize later, like when you talk to a person, their eyes are following you.  All in all, it was a great buy during Christmas and I can recommend it to everybody who loves VR.

Wilson's Heart is not perfect, but it is currently the best story game experience out there.  The story is well-crafted from beginning to end, with lots of twists and turns along the way with a satisfying ending and a mysterious beginning.  It plays like a good horror mystery should.  With just the right pacing and getting to know each of the main characters.  Wilson, the protagonist, is the biggest mystery up until the very end where we see how this ol' crumudgeon is really a kind spirit.  I loved the black and white aesthetic and the great character modeling and development.  Elsa, Bela, Lucy, and Kurt are all memorable characters, each with their own hidden pasts.  As I mentioned, the game is not perfect.  There are problems with some game mechanics, almost every boss fight ends up being repetitive (have to do the same thing 3 times).  The locks can be annoying to open (not because of difficulty, but because of game bugginess).  The teleportation can be off putting for some.  However, the great atmosphere and story really shine and really overshadow the frustrating moments.  I immensely enjoyed the experience and thus can forgive the missteps.  Especially with the high production values and the quality and quantity of content here.  Rating 9/10.  *** Spoilers for avoiding frustration *** 1) at the start, you must find the key in the restroom and then put the key in the outlined area in the upperight hand corner of the screen to progress 2) keep trying the lock, you'll see it working when the animation shows the steel bar stand up 3) you can flip through some notebooks and that is vital for one particular puzzle 4) for some puzzles, keep holding on to the object and look around and you'll see where to go 5) watch the end credits for a final cut scene ****

The puzzles are for the most part intriguing and decently intuitive. The story itself decently ties together the locations and puzzles and Wilson's internal monologue tended to match the tone, if not the theme, of my own thoughts.

This adventure game just gets the VR mechanics done right, from a quick height and language check at the start, to a multi-layer Guardian Wall that does a great job seamlessly preventing you from breaking your own immersion (or real life fist), through well executed item and NPC Touch interaction. While I dislike teleportation in any VR action based game, the teleportation method used here is as quick and convenient as it gets, and this game being more adventure then action I'd even say that free locomotion would do it more harm then good, because the teleportation nodes keep your attention focused where it needs to be. If anything these guys have set the bar to how well designed the Touch mechanics of a (non action based) game can be, both maximizing Touch related potential while minimizing Touch related frustration. It's not that you will find those Touch mechanics amazing, it's just that they do such a great job of fitting in instead of getting in the way of what you want to do (for performing advanced VR interactions that go beyond holding and pointing a gun), that it's easy to forget about them and how well they work. review_title: Frustrating. Story not great. Overall no
one_reviews_text:
This game expects you to know subtle aspects of interacting with the world around you in ways that it simply can not, and should not expect. For example, I got stuck for 10 mins because I couldn't figure out how to open a door (spoiler alert: you needed to use both hands, rather than just one hand). Things like this happen all the time in this game which left me more frustrated than satisfied. Story overall was not great. The game has a great atmophere and maybe even a decent story.  The problem is how movement is handled.  You can only move to predetermined locations in an area and interact with items that are useful for progressing the plot.  Within each of these locations you can only move about one foot in any direction before the game pauses and waits for you to go back to your "interaction point".  This cheapens the experience and kills any feeling of immersion.  The combat is Janky at best and can become extremely frustrating.  Most scenarios come down to figuring out what part of the monster or environment you need to interact with, then doing it three times per "boss".  

Bottom line: If you can get the game on a significant sale, then it's worth a playthrough.

Wilson's Heart is, as the review title suggests, a tale that is well worth your time. The locale, puzzles, and characters draw you in and stay varied enough that you won't get bored over the course of your 8ish hours. The game has some good scares, but they aren't a focus - the asylum's creepy atmosphere and bizarre encounters fill in all the spooky gaps well enough by themselves. 
The game's flaws from the "combat sections". They suffer from 2 major issues. Repetition and being oft unclear as to how to combat your foes. 
Repetition comes in the form of boss fights that are split into parts. These parts generally consist of an up-close and a far-away bit of combat that essentially repeat themselves at least 3 times with very little variation to make them more interesting... More just to fluff the game's play time.
As these fights can be fast paced and sometimes involve the world around you, sometimes the solution to the fight is frustratingly obtuse. This forces you to replay the same bit over and over again until you figure out what you're supposed to do and just want the fight to be over. Gaining new "heart powers" became something I dreaded because it usually meant a fight was coming up.
Combat aside, the puzzles were (with some minor exceptions) engaging, interesting, and made sense. The story had some good twists and mostly decent voice work. Side things like radios and comic books provided fun distractions from everything else going on and sometimes gave context to the characters and world around you. 
In conclusion, Wilson's Heart is a step in the right direction for puzzle based VR titles. Combat isn't great, but isn't a major focus and had some interesting points. This is a must play for VR enthusiasts and hopefully an inspiration for future titles to learn from.

The trailer got me and I purchased the game. I was a bit disappointed though. My two-star rating goes towards the story and general ambiance of the game - both for the black and white horror set in the 40's as well as the music and sound effects. I do not feel as positive however for the puzzles and gameplay style. It feels like this type of gamestyle is outdated for 2017 - similar to Sanitarium (released in 1998). You can only move to predetermind spots and within are a few interactive objects. Those related to the puzzles are outlined and the others can't be carried to be used/tried elsewhere anyway. Basically the puzzles are presolved for you and the game becomes only a "search for the highlighted destinations and objects" game. Little brainpower needed in what lasted me approximately 4 hours of gameplay. Replay value, for me at least, is inexistant. I think  TwistedPixel has potential to make greatness in future VR games though. They just need tougher puzzles, allow players to try anything at anytime in a free roam style and they have a recipe for a game of the year!

I stayed away from this one for a while because I'm not a big fan of scary games in VR. I sound like a bit of a wuss saying that (and I cowered like one in Duck Season) but there it is.  Finally tried it and I am pleased to say, it's not that kind of scary.  Horror game?  Yes.  Violent images?  Sure thing.  Jump scares?  From time to time, but the overall feel of the game doesn't summon dread or terror.  There's a general sense of grim whimsy to the game that reminds me more of The 7th Guest in tone, though the puzzles are not as random and pointless and the story, you know, makes sense.  Mostly.  My only complaint about the game is the solutions to some puzzles work most of the time, and the game can feel like a bit of a cheat when you try the solution in trial-and-error and it doesn't work leading you to try numerous other solutions until you've gone around the horn, try the same thing a second time and then, somehow, get different results.  Last I check that's the very definition of insanity.  Of course, this game DOES take place in an asylum, and the checkpoint system is friendly so you don't get thrown back far when something goes wrong (Syren, take the hint).  Anyhoo, it's a long, engrossing and entertaining experience.  Get this game.  Do it now.  And stay away from Syren.  It's the worst.

review_title: One of the best VR games out there
one_reviews_text: I'm only an hour into the game and I already know this is one of the best VR games currently on the market. Everything about this game is fantastic; the graphics, the sound, the monochrome design, the immersion, the acting (your character actual talks a good amount), the writing, and just about everything else. This game takes full advantage of the touch controllers in that you will literally do anything you can think of; move a cart, release yourself from shakles, pickup a clip board in order to read the controls for the game, and even strike a match. Now that may all sound boring but anyone who has played VR can tell you that even that stuff is amazing. The game itself takes place in a hospital and, to put it bluntly, bad stuff has happened. You wake up all alone with blood seen on hospital beds with nobody in sight and you set out to find out what is going on. I can't go into detail about the story since I just started and game and even if I had beaten the game I wouldn't spoil it but the story is very good in my opinion. The game has a horror vibe and a few jump scares; whether intentional or not. And some really creepy stuff happens. You move around the world by looking for silhouettes of yourself and pointing at the figure to go to where the figure is. Once you are there you can interact with the world in order to progress onward. If you do happen to find something useful, you, literally, put it into your inventory. So no, there is no free movement but please don't let that fact stop you from playing a rich, immersive game. Virtual Reality is still young but with games like Wilson's Heart, the genre is sure to thrive. I honestly can't recommend this game enough so please look up videos on the game and give it a try; you won't be disappointed.

I've been an Oculus owner since the Canadian launch and I haven't enjoyed anything quite like Wilson's Heart. Tense gameplay, amazing story and voice acting and one hell of a finish. Thank you Twisted Pixel!

review_title: The visuals are truly a work of art
one_reviews_text:
I really enjoyed this experience. This game is easily in my top 3 most visually-impressive VR games yet. I found myself staring in awe at the rooms and environments around me on numerous occasions, and could tell that the artist(s) behind this game really poured their heart and soul into it. Even if the gameplay was trash, the visual aspect of this game alone could've launched it to 3 or 4 stars, for me. Before playing it I wasn't sure about the monochrome aesthetic, but I think in a way it really enhanced the immersiveness of the game, making you feel like you're trapped in an eerie 1950s Hitchcock thriller or Twilight Zone episode.

On the cons, I do wish the game offered free locomotion, if only to further explore the gorgeous world you're dropped into. However, the gameplay as it stands relies pretty largely on putting you into the right places, otherwise it would be very difficult and time consuming to try to figure out what to do next.  Even though you are constrained to specific places and vantage points throughout the game, I think the way this was handled worked really well and didn't detract much from the overall experience. As some other reviewers have mentioned, the combat mechanics felt like one of the weakest parts of the game, but it isn't a combat-heavy title either.

The story and audio are also worth a mention. This one drops you into a mystery you're trying to figure out as the game progresses, with a number of twists to keep it interesting. The voice acting in the game is great (it should be considering the list of pro actors in the credits), and the musical score fit the theme nicely too. I should also mention the humor scattered throughout this game, if you go looking hard enough for it... TPS reports anyone?

No game is perfect and this title isn't an exception to that rule, but I can tell they set out to make a truly cinematic experience with this game and I think they succeeded nicely. One of my most enjoyable VR playthroughs yet.

This wouldn’t be so bad until you get to the “Boss” areas where some newbie of a game designer thought it would be fun to send wave after wave of the dull enemies at the player only to have them start at the beginning and repeat the same inane experience.  Someone needs to go back and take Game Design 101.  I stopped playing the game at that point – even the decent story can’t drive bad game play.
BTW – What is with all the lame comic books?  It looks like most of the art resources were spent on non-goal driven assets.

Object interactions are often both unintuitive and inconsistent. The only way to move the story forward is to do EXACTLY the right thing, in the right order and only that order. You'll be helplessly flailing your arms mid air, hoping to grasp something of value, moving the story forward. Before it all is over you'll probably want to pull out your hair in frustration multiple times.

Buy it on a sale, play it for the story, but be prepared to face terrible game design.

review_title: My favorite VR title so far!
one_reviews_text: We just recently bought an Oculus, but we have the Gear VR and Playstation VR and have played a lot of different games. Wilson's Heart is by far my favorite VR experience. The Oculus Touch controllers make it so much more immersive; at one point I even tried to set one of my controllers on a bench in the game because for a second I forgot I was in a game. I loved the characters and the story line. The bosses were all unique and fun to fight. I think the only complaint I had was with the gloves. There are two times during this game where you have to put on gloves to complete tasks and it took me forever to get it to work correctly. Just grabbing them didn't work, and I tried to use my other hands to help put them on (like you would real gloves), but that didn't work either. It took a lot of button pressing to get the gloves on. Maybe I was doing it wrong? I guess if there are certain buttons that need to be pressed, that should probably be made more clear in the game. ‘Wilson’s Heart’ is a unique experience that is absolutely worth playing. Many of the puzzles and scenarios are intriguing and creative, and make delightful use of the sort of dream logic that only works in a virtual environment. The art direction, environments and animations are extremely impressive and rank amongst the very best I’ve seen in any VR game.  The voice acting is great, with Rosario Dawson and Alfred Molina doing particularly good work. However, the game does have a few issues with unnecessary hand-holding (some harder puzzles would have been a good addition) and overly limited interactivity in some areas (why can’t I duck under things that get thrown at me?). The story is an interesting and entertaining mashup of horror movie tropes, but it would have been nice to see a clearer dramatic arc and more character development. I found the combat scenes fun, but I also felt they could have used a bit more variety. That said, given that this is one of the first VR productions on this scale I’m inclined to cut Twisted Pixel some slack here, as the VR industry as a whole is very much still in the “figuring things out” phase. I hope future VR developers will take note of both this game’s flaws and the many things it does very well.

review_title: It's a great game - very unique
one_reviews_text:
There's known recipes to produce pop music, pop arts, pop movies. The same goes for video games. When the recipe is not followed you run the risk of losing a part of 4the audience. One of the ingredient that is expected by many is the freedom of movement. If you have no freedom you can't have a good game. It's VR and you should be able to go and explore everything, interact with everything, touch everything, break everything, eat everything, read all the books in the library, open all doors, etc. 

Well this game doesn't let you roam free all over the place and I like it. If I go to the beach to swim do I need to visit all the houses on my way to the beach? If I go to the fridge to get a snack do I need to explore the entire house before I get to the fridge?
Do I want to spent 25 hours exploring a room inches by inches or do I want the story to advance? In my case I want thing to move along, I want the story to unfold in front of me and I think this game does it very well.

The ingredients are different but the end result is very interesting and entertaining. 
There's more than one way to make a great  game and I like the way they choose.


Edit: I'm done with this game, combat is too repetitive, I'm giving up. Having to throw a electric sphere over and over again just at the right place and at the right moment and be force to restart again and again is not my idea of fun.
I think it's terrible that the only language is English and there are no subtitles, language is a priority for the enjoyment of a game.

I managed to dodge the hype around this and didn't know what to expect. tl;dr - This game is a good early lesson for VR developers, some things are great and others are horrible.

Pros - Graphically pretty despite the B&W asthetic. 
- Good voice acting and animations deliver fair feeling of 'being there'.
- Story is just weird enough to be fun without triggering face-palms.
- The comics are great.
- Physical mechics such as throwing, punching and interacting with objects are done quite well, mostly feeling natural.
- While most of the puzzles are super easy to solve (due to the heavily 'guided' nature of the gameplay) many are inventive and still fun to solve given the supernatural theme.
- Multiple save slots so others can enjoy while you're mid-game (not enough titles have this basic must-have so u can demo).

Cons - The 'boss' battles are largely dull, rinse and repeat affairs for the most part with occasionally wonky combat mechanics that will likely make many scream in frustration.
- The teleport system is the poorest implementation possible. Makes the gameplay feel more like a 2D LucasArts point-and-click than a VR game. 
- If you move more than 40cm from the central standing location the vision blurs and the game pauses. This simply destroys a VR game and there's no gameplay-breaking reason for it as far as I can tell.
-  I understand why they went with B&W, it supports the stories context, but I see in colour so it really pulls me out of 'being there'.
- The save locations are frustrating more often than not. You have no way of knowing when state is saved, no idea where the check points are. Jumping back in and having to re-play 10 minutes cos there was no save after major events is enraging.
- I am very tollerant of motion-sickness and other VR negative effects but for some reason this game makes my eyes tired quite quickly. I have about 60+ titles and none of them do this to me. I can play SuperHotVR or Elite for hours, not this game though.

My biggest complaint in the game is around the game play. 

Some of the interaction were really strict and just felt a little awkward performing them. Also the puzzles could have been a bit more creative. Many of them have you search around until you find an item and that item will allow you to perform a task at another node. However it highlights when that item is useable so it sort of gives it away.  I really enjoyed the puzzles in the painting section.

Another thing is that the boss fights are pretty simplistic and you basically cycle through 2 or 3 phases until you beat the boss.

Another frustration is that you die in a single hit which seems very unnecessary in a narrative focused game. For example, there will be some exposition going on and then a boss interaction happens. If you get hit, it restarts you have to watch the same 10-15 interaction and try again. It seems like it would make more sense to allow you to take 2-3 hits to get your bearings. I noticed this a lot towards the end and it just killed the momentum of the final scenes.

The game took about 5ish hours I would say to beat, but I had seem some of the preview footage of the beginning.

Overall I enjoyed the game and hope to see more from Twisted Pixel.

Oh. My. God. This game is amazing. First off, be aware that the gameplay is very much inspired by classic adventure games like Myst. The movement is node-based and the game deliberately funnels you through setpieces that remind me of the Tower of Terror ride at Disneyland. The black-and-white graphics somehow work brilliantly, and the game has some legitimate scares. My one complaint is the same I had when Robo Recall was launched... although the game encourages you to turn 360 degrees frequently, you aren't ever facing the "correct" direction when you jump between nodes. I'm sure it's designed this way for people with only 2 sensors... forcing you to reorient yourself every time you "move". It's a bit disorienting, but not in a good way. That aside, the game is absolutely dripping with brilliant VR ideas: a little Twilight Zone, a little Lovecraft, and oodles and oodles of creepy atmosphere, gorgeous visuals, and movie-quality storytelling. If the developers fix the movement system for people with 3+ sensors, this is easily 5 stars and the best VR game to date.

Add a pinch of David Lynch, tiny bit of William S Burroughs,  a dash of Ed Wood, a sprinkle of The Twilight Zone, a handful of Kafka, and a little Love Craft.  Stir and serve it with some film noir.

The most full-featured, polished game currently on the Oculus Store. If you want to taste the potential of Rift with Touch and VR in general, this is the game.
===
Not having the ability to move around yourself, and not having an inventory you can manage yourself, reduces a LOT of puzzle-solving to 1) look around, 2) use a collected object when it appears in the corner of your eye. A little mindless, but the cool objects and machines you get to handle, helps make up for it. The node-based directional teleportation mechanic of Robo Recall, is just a straight-up improvement over movement here.
===
The game is more about puzzles than jump scares, but there are some good jump scares, and there's definitely some creepiness.
===
If you can get used to the restrictive movement and inventory, the game is REALLY satisfying from a story and artistic angle, ESPECIALLY if you love classic black and white horror movies.
===
Possible improvements for a patch (hopefully the devs read these): 
===
1) make the ghost avatars of the player, optional, with an option for some footprints instead, which would prevent damaging the sense of isolation and immersion.
===
2) enable an option that puts footprints on the ground where the player must stand, since there's no way to physically recenter yourself currently, without just stepping really far from your planted position, which causes the game to freeze in a super-immersion breaking way, creating a ghost avatar of yourself that people can actually get scared by when it appears. I had to put a patterned floor mat below me, to see out the bottom of the Rift, just to check where I was, which wouldn't be necessary if the game wasn't SO unforgiving about moving a foot or two to the side - or just had some little glowing footprints for me to move back to.
